[1]Yes, now if you could stay on the phone for a moment and talk to me, just talk to me. I'm not even clear, I don't actually understand what it is I'm trying to order. Is wireless the same as wi-fi? And what do either of them have to do with broadband? 
[2]What? 
[3]You can't talk to him, no. He's dead. He died. There's only me. 
[4]That's what your father used to say. 
[5]When there'd never really been any discussion at all. 
[6]Like he did for forty years 
[7]And look how that turned out. She turns to Harold 
[8]How can any of us know what Hugh would've wanted? And would he have seen fit to tell us anyway? Obviously the flat has to be sold.  And you're very kind. And dear Polly. But no, I won't be coming to live with you. 
[9]How far along is the progress bar? The strip at the bottom that tells you -

[16]What larks, Pip. Douglas is just ahead of her. He turns, smiles.

[18]A little. 
[19]No.

[24]Oh, hello.

[28]That too. 
[29]How did you come to be here? In India. 
[30]I'm not sure I understand what most of those words mean. 
[31]Really? 
[32]He moved! He's alive! 
[33]Day Nine. Old habits die easier than we think, and new ones form. 
[34]No longer do I reach out in the morning for Radio 4. My news comes instead from the Jaipur 
[35]. Soon I might even grow accustomed to the storm of car horns and vendors. 
[36]Can there be anywhere else in the world that is such an assault on the senses? 
[37]Those who know the country of old just go about their business. But nothing can prepare the uninitiated for this riot of noise and colour ... 
[38]... for the heat, the motion, the perpetual teeming crowds. Sonny is conducting his own personal assault on our senses 
[39]with the flow of exotic dishes he demands daily from the kitchen. Mooli Moong Dal. Baghara Baingan. Banjari Gosht. Paneer Methi Chaman ... As the list unfolds, the guests, one by one, enter their bathrooms; a litany of doors closing Until Norman. EVELYN  (cont'd) Mutton Vindaloo ... Norman lies on his bed, reading the Kama Sutra. He spins the book round, in order to study an illustration more intently. 
[40]Initially you're overwhelmed. But gradually you realise: it's like a wave. Resist, and you'll be knocked over ... Sonny is in discussion with some doctors. Then he turns to see that Muriel has vanished. Through the window Muriel can be seen frantically wheeling herself away down the path... EVELYN  (cont'd) Dive into it, and you'll swim out the other side. 
[41]This is a new and different world. 
[42]The challenge is to cope with it. 
[43]And not just cope ... but thrive. 
[44]Please, can anyone direct me to this address? Evelyn's piece of paper gets passed around: none of the kids can read. An older boy finally points. Suddenly there's lots of pointing. 
[45]Thank you. She goes to move, but the kids are still all around her. 
[46]I'm sorry, I don't . I don't really have much ... She gives them the contents of her pockets. 
[47]Alright? Alright now? Goodbye. She starts to walk, is surprised that the entire posse of kids walks with her. In fact, the group seems to be growing exponentially. She looks like the Pied Piper. 
[48]I'm so sorry. I didn't realise - She backs into a kind of flatbed trolley, piled high with cooking utensils, which clatter noisily to the ground. She goes to pick them up. 
[49]Oh, I'm dreadfully sorry... A man is staring at her: SURESH. 
[50]I'm sorry, I'm just trying to get to this address. 
[51]Do you understand me? Can you help me find this place? 
[52]Is that yes you understand, or yes you can help me? 
[53]Let's go with both, shall we? 
[54]Thank you. 
[55]This is it? 
[56]Then thank you. You're very kind. 
[57]Builder's tea. It's called builder's tea. And no, I'm fine. Thank you. 
[58]I don't think you can. I'm sorry, I shouldn't have come. She stands. 
[59]I saw your advertisement in the local paper, and it specifically mentioned the ability to talk to older people. But this is not what I imagined ... 
[60]I've wasted your time. 
[61]I see that. Good day. 
[62]Yes. We dunk biscuits into it. 
[63]It means lowering a biscuit into your tea, letting it soak in there, then trying to calculate the exact moment just before it dissolves to whip it up to the mouth, and enjoy the blissful union of biscuit and tea combined. It's more relaxing than it sounds. 
[64]Good evening. Evelyn sits at her table. 
[65]I trust you had a good day? 
[66]I got a job. My first. Ever. I'm going to be a sort of cultural advisor. 
[67]Perhaps if you wouldn't mind keeping that news to yourself. 
[68]Have you had a good day? 
[69]I'd like that very much. 
[70]Goodnight. 
[71]Evelyn. 
[72]Until now. 
[73]Do you want to see him again? 
[74]Then you must. 
[75].You ring in the morning. Let's assume the person answering will be a woman. She will have had her breakfast. Tea or coffee. Semi-skimmed milk, always. If she's under 50 she'll be contemplating yet another diet, over 50 she'll have more or less given up, and be eating toast. The radio may be playing, or more likely daytime TV. A chat show, or a programme with a moderator speaking to a panel of young women whose boyfriends have all slept with their mothers. The girlfriends' mothers, I mean, not their own. Although Anyway, then the boyfriends usually come out, and everybody fights. Sunaina is in the audience. She calls out. 
[76]That's the point. When the phone rings and it's this robot nobody wants a machine, but it's almost worse when it's a person behaving like one. All these sales cliches just strung together. 'Your call is important to us'. Is it? Well then sound like it. 
[77]Right. That one. Don't ever say that. 
[78]Yes, when your middle name is 
[79]Which is beautiful. You people are young, vibrant, real. I'm sure the typical housewife would enjoy talking to each and every one of you. 
[80]I suppose I'm not typical anymore. Is that the sort of thing? 
[81]Day 22. Like Darwin's finches, we are slowly adapting to our environment. And when one does adapt, my god, the riches that are available. Madge looks across the bar. And is startled to see Norman and Carol chatting up a storm, laughing together. As she watches, Norman orders more drinks, then turns smiling back to his new friend. Madge walks slowly out of the bar, and into the night. 
[82]There is no past that we can bring back by longing for it 
[83]. only a present that builds and creates itself as the past withdraws ... 
[84]And India, like so many things in life, like life itself I suppose, is about what you bring to it. 
[85]Bow much for this, please Kitna 
[86]Thank you. She reaches for her wallet. Then Douglas speaks from behind her. 
[87]Good morning. 
[88]

[90]Do you think so? 
[91]Eight hundred and fifty, nine hundred, nine hundred and fifty, one thousand. She turns to Douglas, smiles. 
[92]You'll get him next time. Then she notices something. 
[93]Why are you carrying a tap?

But when the ride began I felt mine give a little, like it might collapse. Then these strong arms were around me, holding the horse together. And a voice in my ear said "Just trust me". And I did. Without question. Until the day he died. 
[95]The sale of our flat went through last week. I had to sell it to pay off Hugh's debts. I've been forced to get a job out here. Which, in fact, I love. But even at Sonny's rates, I still couldn't make ends meet. After what my own husband did to our life savings. So no. You're right. You never know. Jamshed holds up the tap. Which is now in several parts. 
[96]Anything? 
[97]How about now? 
[98]What?

[100]Do excuse me. She makes a tactful exit. Jean is going past Douglas into their room. 
[101]I've been getting out and about as much as I can, but I feel I've hardly scratched the surface. And of course I'd love to see Udaipur. The lake you talked about. 
[102]I think you should knock on the door and see. 
[103]What was she thinking? 
[104]His wife. Manoj's wife. She knew who Graham was. Had he told her? D'you think we'll find out tomorrow? 
[105]Tell me. 
[106]Sunaina? And now Sunaina is even more humiliated. 
[107]You're back. He doesn't turn round. Evelyn has come out to the garden. She goes over to him. 
[108]It's been rather an extraordinary night all round. First tell me your news, and then - She breaks off. Graham is dead. 
[109]Day 45. Of course it was inevitable. Put enough old people in the same place, it won't be too long before one of them goes... Jean, Douglas, Madge, Norman and Muriel shocked and sobered 
[110]We all know it'll happen, but few of us know when. Graham died of a heart attack, evidently not his first. So he had a better idea than most what was coming, he just neglected to tell us. His prerogative. 
[111]There was talk of sending the body home, but Manoj felt he should have a Hindu burial. At the place they had visited together. Not a holy place. Although for them perhaps it was. 
[112]A body takes a long time to be consumed. Many hours for the mourners to remember their dead. The fire must be lit at dawn, and by sunset, there must be nothing left but ash. 
[113]Where do our souls go? is that all of us that is left behind? Perhaps the most we can ask is that when we do shuffle off, we do so knowing that we were loved Manoj pours Graham onto the water. The ashes shim r and dance, caught in the gentle currents. 
[114]I went to see Gaurika. Manoj's wife. I wanted to ask her what she knew. And the answer was that she knew everything, that he'd loved another man, and always would. He told her when the marriage was arranged. They had no secrets from each other, none. Suddenly she's crying. Unable to stop. Douglas puts his arms around her, and holds her to him. 
[115]And that's right, don't you see? That must be right. Because what is the point of a marriage in which nothing is shared? Her words hang in the air. They stand there for a moment. Jean has come out of her room, and stands there, watching them. 
[116]Yes, of course. 
[117]I just need some water. She drains the glass. 
[118]Yes. I know that now. 
[119]I'm actually going to walk. Apparently they're getting ready for a festival. 
[120]I'll be fine. Evelyn speaks to both Douglas and Jean. 
[121]I'm delighted for your daughter's success. I wish you all every happiness. 
[122]I just wanted to hear your voice. No, I'm sorry, I didn't think about the time . How are you? And Polly? The boys . how are the boys? She listens to him. She's holding back tears. 
[123]Oh good, I'm glad you've been reading it. Yes. Yes, I've made some very good friends. No, I'm fine, of course I am. As much as she had wanted to speak to him, she now wants the conversation to be over. 
[124]I think my money is running out, I'd better go. Goodbye for now, darling. I'll call again later. She hangs up. And stays there with her hand on the phone. Out on the street, Sonny is pulling up. She looks over to him. 
[125]They're on their way to the hotel. Sonny looks around, at a loss. 
[126]What's the matter? 
[127]What are you talking about? 
[128]What? 
[129]But what about your girlfriend? 
[130]This is a disaster. 
[131]Sonny, do you love her? Sunaina? 
[132]Have you told her you love her? 
[133]And you have told her that? 
[134]Good. Women love it when you say that kind of thing. It's a powerful aphrodisiac. 
[135]No, of course not. Go and find her right now, before you lose her forever. Her future is hers to choose, and so is yours. You can have anything you want, Sonny. You just need to stop waiting for someone to tell you you deserve it. Or you can just keep failing yourself, and hurting the ones you love - 
[136]What about me, Mrs Donnelly? 
[137]My loss, evidently. I'm not sure what I should do. Nothing here has quite worked out as I hoped. 
[138]You don't know him. He's the most loyal man I've ever met. 
[139]Day 51. The only real failure is the failure to try. 
[140]And the measure of success is how we cope with disappointment. As we always must. 
[141]We came here, and we tried. All of us, in our different ways. 
[142]Some achieved more than others. but we did our best. Nothing else matters. Evelyn walks through the courtyard, and on out of the hotel. 
[143]Good morning. 
[144]You're still here. 
[145]What about Jean? 
[146]I'm late for work. She goes past him. 
[147]I get back about 5. 
[148]Yes. 
[149]With a little milk. She turns and walks away. She's smiling. 
[150]Perhaps it's true: we don't stop playing because we grow old, we grow old because we stop playing. Douglas is haggling with a motorbike mechanic. He seems to be having more success with the price than in earlier days. 
[151]Let them come. Bring them on. Because as someone once said, everything will be alright in the end ... Coming from the other direction, another motorbike, Douglas at the handlebars, returning Sonny's greeting. And on the pillion seat, riding side-saddle, her scarf flying in the breeze, is Evelyn, on her way home from work. EVELYN  (cont'd) So if it's really not alright, then trust me: it's not yet the end.
dialogues.SONNY:
[1]Welcome to India!!! They stare up at him. 
[2]This is a building of the utmost character, which means that perhaps not everything will function in the way you expect it to. But as the manager and chief executive supervising officer of the Marigold Hotel, I can tell you with great pride that the building has stood for centuries, and will stand for many more, in 100% shipshape condition. Please follow me, carefully avoiding that naughty stone there round this corner, leading us most successfully all the way to . your bedroom! The room is very small, comfortable, and tastefully decorated. But there's no door. 
[3]Here. In here. 
[4]The door is coming soon, most definitely. 
[5]Let us not concern ourselves with details, Mrs Hardcastle. Rather than speaking of doors, we should instead take pleasure in the freedom to roam. 
[6]Oh yes. 
[7]Mrs Ainslie, prepare to be amazed. This is that very building! 
[8]I have offered a vision of the future. 
[9]Of course I had hoped that by now it would be the present. But in India we have a saying: everything will be alright in the end. So if it is not alright, then it is not yet the end. 
[10]Of course if that is what you desire, you must have it. Absolutely no problem, I will refund you completely. 
[11]Without question, Mrs Ainslie, I most definitely will. Straight away in three months. 
[12]In honour of your arrival, a special welcome British roast for you all! 
[13].Cooked lovingly by myself and my most loyalist factotum and helper, Young Wasim ... He points to YOUNG WASIM. Who is about 80, and is sitting in the corner, fast asleep. 
[14]A wonderful taste of Blighty. 
[15]Roast goat curry. 
[16]Gentle friends, you have found your way to this place, bequeathed to me by my beloved father, that I have raised from the ruins of his broken dreams, and renamed The Best Exotic Marigold Hotel For The Elderly And Beautiful. Yes, I use the words most deliberately... Norman is not looking very well at all. Sonny doesn't notice, keeps on going.

[18]Let me through, please. My brother is a doctor. He kneels next to Norman, and checks his watch as he feels for a pulse. Everybody waits. And then

[62]Come after. Come late

[67]Mr Dashwood! Everybody! Great news!

Mr Maruthi looks down, sees Muriel. She's with Anokhi, Ajit, and Young Wasim. He calls down to her. 
[80]And now if you would please be following me to the ground floor

[83]Working for me, Mr Maruthi. To create a home for the elderly so wonderful that they will simply refuse to die! Stare death in the face and say-

[87]You joke, Mummyji, but inside I know you are not laughing. You do not want to see this dream destroyed. Send these people away. 
[88]Mummyji, please -

[95]I am delighted to announce the closing of the Best Exotic Marigold Hotel, and the joyful return of all of its inhabitants to their home country. 
[96]And for myself the news is even better. I shall be moving to Delhi to live with my mother, and furthermore I shall be wed to a most suitable person of her choice, whom I look forward very much to meeting before I spend the rest of my life with her. 
[97]She is no longer my girlfriend. 
[98]Then we must treat it just the same as we would treat a triumph, is that not what your Mr Kipling tells us? Although of course, here we have a problem. Because I, Sunil Indrajit Kapoor, have never had a triumph, so of course I do not know how to treat one. No, all I have had is an constant series of disasters interspersed with the occasional catastrophe, an unending stream of total - 
[99]Most deeply. 
[100]It is because I love her that I must not tell her. She can do so much better than me. 
[101]Many times. 
[102]Really?

[104]Sunaina! Sunaina! He reaches the seventh floor. Jay appears on the landing above him. 
[105]I need to see Sunaina!

[108]Tell her from me what I should have told her the day we met. What I will announce to anyone who asks. And many who do not. Sunaina speaks to Jay.

The woman I love, and wish to marry.
